Director Tom Ford films all of this so elegantly with a designer's eye, every shot precisely framed, that for a time it seems he might actually be making things too stylish: sleek '60s clothing, a house out of Architectural Digest.
The filming is so controlled it feels a little airless.
But as the beige-on-gray visuals glow with warmer colors when emotions flare, you realize this director has made style strategic.

George is a man who manages his feelings, and visualizing him in such pristine terms lets Ford highlight the tiniest of gestures: the finessing he does to navigate a can't-ask-can't-tell world and the glimmers of hope that flare unexpectedly at the edges of despair.
For ""A Single Man,"" despite all George's grief, is about someone who's finally learning to live in the moment, a moment that Ford makes at once wrenching and ravishing.
